title: 115_s1811
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Merger Enforcement Improvement Act" and includes provisions related to premerger notification filing fees. Section 605 of Public Law 101-162 (15 U.S.C. 18a note) is amended to adjust various monetary thresholds and dates related to premerger notification filing fees. The monetary thresholds and dates related to premerger notification filing fees are adjusted as follows: $250,000 is inserted, $1,000,000,000 is the minimum amount, and $2,000,000,000 is the maximum amount for different scenarios under the Clayton Act. The filing fees under the Clayton Act are adjusted annually based on the percentage increase in the Producer Price Index. The minimum amount is $250,000, and the maximum amount ranges from $2,000,000,000 to $5,000,000,000 depending on the scenario. The Federal Trade Commission adjusts filing fees under the Clayton Act annually based on the percentage increase in the Producer Price Index. Adjusted amounts are published by January 31 each year and rounded to the nearest multiple of $5,000 if the increase is at least 1 percent. SEC. 3. POST-SETTLEMENT DATA. Section 7A of the Clayton Act is amended to require persons entering agreements with the FTC or the US to submit annual information for 5 years regarding the competitive impact of acquisitions. This includes details on pricing, availability, and quality of products or services in relevant markets. The amended Section 7A of the Clayton Act mandates that parties in agreements with the FTC or US must provide annual information for 5 years on the competitive effects of acquisitions, including cost-saving efficiencies, consumer benefits, and the effectiveness of divestitures in preserving competition. The amended Section 7A of the Clayton Act requires parties to provide detailed information relevant to proposed acquisitions to assess competitive impact. This includes defining terms, exempting irrelevant information, and prescribing necessary rules. SEC. 4. FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION STUDY.

Within 2 years of this Act's enactment, the Federal Trade Commission, with input from the Securities and Exchange Commission, will conduct a study on institutional investors' ownership interests in competitors, economic impacts, and mechanisms affecting competition.

SEC. 5. GAO STUDIES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct studies on the success of merger remedies and the impact of mergers on various aspects like wages, employment, and innovation. These studies will be updated periodically based on information provided under the Clayton Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct studies on the success of merger remedies and the impact of mergers on wages, employment, and innovation. The studies will be based on information provided under section 7A(l) of the Clayton Act, as added by section 3 of this Act, and will identify specific remedies or alleged merger benefits that require additional information or research. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2018: $180,606,000 for the Antitrust Division of the Department of Justice and $342,000,000 for the Federal Trade Commission.
